text:
Research on the biological basis of sexual orientation has examined twin studies. What do monozygotic (identical) twin concordance rates suggest?
A) Sexual orientation has a significant heritable component, with MZ concordance rates of 20-50% depending on study methodology
B) Sexual orientation is entirely genetic, with 100% concordance in identical twins
C) Twin studies show no genetic influence on sexual orientation
Answer:
answers: Significant heritable component, 20-50% MZ concordance
Entirely genetic, 100% concordance
No genetic influence
citation: Bailey et al. 2000, Archives of General Psychiatry; Langstrom et al. 2010, Archives of Sexual Behavior

text:
The fraternal birth order effect is one of the most replicated findings in sexual orientation research. What does it show?
A) Each older brother increases the probability of male homosexuality by approximately 33%
B) Birth order has no relationship to sexual orientation
C) Having older sisters increases probability of male homosexuality
Answer:
answers: Each older brother increases probability by ~33%
Birth order has no relationship to sexual orientation
Having older sisters increases probability
citation: Blanchard 2018, Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences; Bogaert 2006, PNAS

text:
The proposed biological mechanism for the fraternal birth order effect involves:
A) Maternal immune response to male-specific antigens (e.g., NLGN4Y protein), with progressive immunization across successive male pregnancies
B) Psychological competition between brothers for parental attention
C) Social learning from older siblings during childhood
Answer:
answers: Maternal immune response to male-specific antigens (NLGN4Y protein)
Psychological competition between brothers
Social learning from older siblings
citation: Bogaert et al. 2018, PNAS; Blanchard 2018

text:
Simon LeVay's 1991 study on the hypothalamus reported what finding about INAH-3 (third interstitial nucleus of the anterior hypothalamus)?
A) INAH-3 was on average smaller in homosexual men compared to heterosexual men, similar in size to that of women
B) No structural brain differences were found between homosexual and heterosexual men
C) Homosexual men had larger INAH-3 nuclei than heterosexual men
Answer:
answers: INAH-3 smaller in homosexual men, similar to women
No structural brain differences found
Larger INAH-3 in homosexual men
citation: LeVay 1991, Science 253:1034-1037

text:
The largest genome-wide association study (GWAS) on sexual orientation to date found:
A) Five genetic loci significantly associated with same-sex behavior, but these collectively explain less than 1% of variance — there is no single 'gay gene'
B) A single gene on chromosome 8 that determines sexual orientation
C) No genetic markers associated with sexual orientation
Answer:
answers: Five significant loci, <1% variance explained, no single 'gay gene'
A single gene on chromosome 8
No genetic markers found
citation: Ganna et al. 2019, Science 365:eaat7693

text:
What does the Ganna et al. (2019) GWAS study conclude about the genetic architecture of sexual orientation?
A) It is highly polygenic — influenced by many genetic variants of small effect, similar to height or personality traits
B) It follows a simple Mendelian inheritance pattern
C) Genetics plays no role; sexual orientation is entirely environmental
Answer:
answers: Highly polygenic, many variants of small effect
Simple Mendelian inheritance
Genetics plays no role
citation: Ganna et al. 2019, Science 365:eaat7693

text:
Regarding prenatal hormonal exposure and sexual orientation, what does the evidence suggest?
A) Atypical prenatal androgen exposure is associated with increased rates of non-heterosexual orientation, as observed in women with congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH)
B) Prenatal hormones have no influence on sexual orientation
C) High testosterone in utero always produces heterosexual orientation in males
Answer:
answers: Atypical prenatal androgen exposure associated with non-heterosexual orientation (CAH evidence)
Prenatal hormones have no influence
High testosterone always produces heterosexual orientation
citation: Meyer-Bahlburg et al. 2008, Archives of Sexual Behavior; Hines 2011, Hormones and Behavior

text:
What is the current scientific consensus on whether sexual orientation can be changed through therapy ('conversion therapy')?
A) Major medical and psychological organizations (APA, WHO) conclude there is no reliable evidence it works, and it can cause harm
B) Conversion therapy has a high success rate according to peer-reviewed research
C) No studies have been conducted on conversion therapy outcomes
Answer:
answers: No reliable evidence of efficacy, can cause harm (APA, WHO position)
High success rate in peer-reviewed research
No studies conducted
citation: APA Task Force 2009; Przeworski et al. 2020, Clinical Psychology Review

text:
Same-sex sexual behavior has been documented in approximately how many animal species?
A) Over 1,500 species across mammals, birds, reptiles, fish, and invertebrates
B) Only in humans and a few primate species
C) It has never been observed in non-human animals
Answer:
answers: Over 1,500 species across multiple taxa
Only humans and a few primates
Never observed in non-human animals
citation: Bagemihl 1999, Biological Exuberance; Bailey & Zuk 2009, Trends in Ecology & Evolution

text:
The 'sexually antagonistic selection' hypothesis proposes that:
A) Genetic variants that increase homosexuality in one sex may increase reproductive fitness in the other sex, maintaining these alleles in the population
B) Homosexuality is a genetic error that should be eliminated by natural selection
C) Sexual orientation has no evolutionary explanation
Answer:
answers: Genetic variants increasing homosexuality in one sex may increase fitness in the other
Homosexuality is a genetic error
No evolutionary explanation exists
citation: Camperio Ciani et al. 2004, Proceedings of the Royal Society B; Zietsch et al. 2008

text:
Evidence supporting the sexually antagonistic selection hypothesis includes:
A) Female maternal relatives of homosexual men have significantly higher fecundity (more offspring) than female relatives of heterosexual men
B) Homosexual individuals have more offspring than heterosexual individuals
C) There is no empirical support for this hypothesis
Answer:
answers: Female maternal relatives of homosexual men have higher fecundity
Homosexual individuals have more offspring
No empirical support exists
citation: Camperio Ciani et al. 2004, 2009, 2012; Iemmola & Camperio Ciani 2009

text:
What does research on the digit ratio (2D:4D, the ratio of index to ring finger length) suggest about prenatal androgen exposure and sexual orientation?
A) Homosexual women tend to have lower (more masculinized) 2D:4D ratios, consistent with higher prenatal androgen exposure
B) There is no relationship between digit ratio and sexual orientation
C) Heterosexual women have lower 2D:4D ratios than homosexual women
Answer:
answers: Homosexual women have lower (more masculinized) 2D:4D ratios
No relationship between digit ratio and orientation
Heterosexual women have lower 2D:4D ratios
citation: Manning et al. 2007; Grimbos et al. 2010, Archives of Sexual Behavior (meta-analysis)

text:
The 'kin selection' hypothesis for the evolutionary maintenance of homosexuality proposes that:
A) Homosexual individuals may increase their inclusive fitness by helping raise nieces and nephews, thereby passing on shared genes indirectly
B) Homosexuality serves no evolutionary function
C) Homosexual individuals always reproduce through heterosexual encounters
Answer:
answers: Inclusive fitness via helping raise nieces and nephews
No evolutionary function
Reproduction through heterosexual encounters
citation: Wilson 1975, Sociobiology; Vasey et al. 2007, Evolution and Human Behavior (Samoan fa'afafine study)

text:
Evidence for the kin selection hypothesis from Samoan fa'afafine (male-bodied individuals attracted to men) shows:
A) Fa'afafine exhibit significantly elevated avuncular (uncle-like) tendencies — more willingness to invest in nieces and nephews than heterosexual men
B) Fa'afafine show no increased investment in kin
C) Fa'afafine have more biological children than heterosexual Samoan men
Answer:
answers: Elevated avuncular investment in nieces and nephews
No increased investment in kin
More biological children than heterosexual men
citation: Vasey & VanderLaan 2010, Psychological Science; VanderLaan & Vasey 2012

text:
Regarding epigenetic mechanisms and sexual orientation, what has been proposed?
A) Sexually dimorphic epigenetic marks (DNA methylation patterns) from the parent of the opposite sex may sometimes carry across generations, influencing offspring sexual orientation
B) Epigenetics has been conclusively proven to cause homosexuality
C) Epigenetic mechanisms have no relationship to sexual development
Answer:
answers: Sexually dimorphic epigenetic marks may carry across generations (proposed model)
Epigenetics conclusively proven to cause homosexuality
Epigenetics has no relationship to sexual development
citation: Rice et al. 2012, The Quarterly Review of Biology; Ngun & Vilain 2014

text:
Regarding the neuroscience of sexual orientation, brain imaging studies have shown:
A) Differences in hemispheric asymmetry and amygdala connectivity patterns between homosexual and heterosexual individuals, with homosexual men showing patterns more similar to heterosexual women
B) No neurological differences between homosexual and heterosexual individuals
C) Homosexual orientation is caused by brain damage or pathology
Answer:
answers: Differences in hemispheric asymmetry and amygdala connectivity
No neurological differences found
Caused by brain damage or pathology
citation: Savic & Lindstrom 2008, PNAS; Ponseti et al. 2006, NeuroImage

text:
What do otoacoustic emission (OAE) studies suggest about prenatal influences on sexual orientation?
A) Homosexual and bisexual women show weaker otoacoustic emissions (a marker of prenatal androgen exposure) compared to heterosexual women
B) Otoacoustic emissions are identical across all sexual orientations
C) Heterosexual women show weaker emissions than homosexual women
Answer:
answers: Homosexual/bisexual women show weaker OAEs (prenatal androgen marker)
OAEs identical across orientations
Heterosexual women show weaker emissions
citation: McFadden & Pasanen 1998, PNAS; McFadden 2002, Audiology & Neuro-Otology

text:
Research on the X-chromosome region Xq28 and male sexual orientation has shown:
A) Initial linkage (Hamer et al. 1993) was partially replicated in some studies but not others — the effect is real but modest, consistent with polygenic architecture
B) Xq28 is the definitive 'gay gene' that fully determines male sexual orientation
C) The Xq28 linkage was completely disproven and retracted
Answer:
answers: Initial linkage partially replicated, effect modest, consistent with polygenicity
Definitive 'gay gene' that determines orientation
Completely disproven and retracted
citation: Hamer et al. 1993, Science; Sanders et al. 2015, Psychological Medicine

text:
What did the largest study of sexual orientation and parenting (Gartrell & Bos, 2010) find about children raised by same-sex parents?
A) Children of lesbian mothers scored higher on social, academic, and total competence and lower in problem behavior compared to population norms
B) Children of same-sex parents showed significant developmental deficits
C) No studies have examined outcomes for children of same-sex parents
Answer:
answers: Higher competence, lower problem behavior compared to population norms
Significant developmental deficits
No studies have examined this
citation: Gartrell & Bos 2010, Pediatrics; NLLFS longitudinal study (25+ years)

text:
The biological basis of sexual orientation is best characterized as:
A) A complex trait influenced by multiple genetic, hormonal, immunological, and possibly epigenetic factors, with no single cause — similar to other complex behavioral traits
B) Entirely determined by a single gene
C) Entirely a matter of personal choice with no biological basis
Answer:
answers: Complex trait: multiple genetic, hormonal, immunological, epigenetic factors
Entirely determined by a single gene
Entirely a personal choice, no biological basis
citation: Bailey et al. 2016, Psychological Science in the Public Interest (comprehensive review)

text:
Cross-cultural studies of sexual orientation show:
A) Same-sex attraction and behavior occur across all studied human cultures and throughout recorded history, suggesting a biological basis rather than cultural origin
B) Homosexuality exists only in Western industrialized societies
C) Same-sex behavior was unknown before the 20th century
Answer:
answers: Occurs across all studied cultures and throughout history
Exists only in Western industrialized societies
Unknown before the 20th century
citation: Herdt 1997, Same Sex, Different Cultures; Boswell 1980, Christianity, Social Tolerance, and Homosexuality

text:
Regarding the stability of sexual orientation over time, longitudinal research shows:
A) For most individuals, sexual orientation is stable over the lifespan, though some individuals (particularly women) show more fluidity — this variation itself may have a biological basis
B) Sexual orientation changes frequently and easily throughout life
C) Sexual orientation is always 100% fixed from birth with zero variation
Answer:
answers: Mostly stable; some fluidity (especially in women) may have biological basis
Changes frequently and easily throughout life
Always 100% fixed from birth
citation: Diamond 2008, Sexual Fluidity; Savin-Williams et al. 2012, Developmental Psychology

text:
The 'exotic becomes erotic' (EBE) theory of Daryl Bem proposes that:
A) Biological variables (genes, hormones) influence childhood temperament, which leads to feeling different from same-sex or opposite-sex peers, and this feeling of difference is later eroticized
B) Sexual orientation is purely learned through social conditioning
C) Sexual orientation is determined entirely at conception with no developmental component
Answer:
answers: Biological variables → temperament → feeling different → eroticization of unfamiliarity
Purely learned through social conditioning
Entirely determined at conception
citation: Bem 1996, Psychological Review; note: this theory remains debated

text:
Studies of pheromone processing in homosexual versus heterosexual men show:
A) Homosexual men's hypothalamic response to the male pheromone AND (androstadienone) is similar to that of heterosexual women, suggesting neurobiological differences in chemosensory processing
B) No differences in pheromone processing have been found
C) Homosexual men cannot detect pheromones at all
Answer:
answers: Hypothalamic response to male pheromone similar to heterosexual women
No differences in pheromone processing found
Cannot detect pheromones at all
citation: Savic et al. 2005, PNAS; Berglund et al. 2006, PNAS

text:
What did Byne et al. (2001) find when replicating LeVay's INAH-3 study with improved methodology?
A) INAH-3 volume did not significantly differ, but neuronal count was significantly lower in homosexual men — confirming a structural difference with more precision
B) No differences whatsoever were found, completely disproving LeVay
C) The hypothalamus has no role in sexual behavior
Answer:
answers: Volume not significant, but neuronal count significantly lower in homosexual men
No differences found, completely disproving LeVay
Hypothalamus has no role in sexual behavior
citation: Byne et al. 2001, Hormones and Behavior 40:86-92
